markdownRemark.html:
In the 2nd and 3rd post, we discuss two forms of translations - rotations and time-evolutions. But wait, we haven’t even talked about linear translation!

  • The Position Space

  • The Translation Operator

    • The Commutator of the Position and Momentum Operator
    • The Ehrenfest Theorem and The Correspondence Principle
    • The Momentum Operator in the Position Space

  • The Momentum Space

  • The Solutions to the Schrödinger Equation

  • References

The Position Space

Before even talking about the translation operator, we need to think about what space, or what basis states we should use. Obviously, translations are closely related to positions, and it would be convenient to have the position space. In this post, we will first deal with 1D space for simplicity. We define a position operator x^\hat xx^:

x^∣x⟩=x∣x⟩\hat x |x\rangle = x |x\ranglex^∣x⟩=x∣x⟩

where ∣x⟩|x\rangle∣x⟩ is an eigenstate of x^\hat xx^in the position space, and xxx is the 1D position. Unlike angular momentum space we’ve dealt with, the position space have infinite many eigenstates, and we need to be more careful with the mathematical notations.

For a general state ψ\psiψ, we can represent it as the superposition of position eigenstates:

∣ψ⟩=∫−∞∞dx∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩|\psi\rangle = \int_{-\infty}^\infty dx |x\rangle\langle x|\psi\rangle∣ψ⟩=∫−∞∞​dx∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩

and its conjugate,

⟨ψ∣=∫−∞∞dx⟨ψ∣x⟩⟨x∣\langle \psi| = \int_{-\infty}^\infty dx \langle \psi|x\rangle\langle x|⟨ψ∣=∫−∞∞​dx⟨ψ∣x⟩⟨x∣

If we apply this relationship to an eigenstate ∣x′⟩|x'\rangle∣x′⟩, we will obtain an important relationship:

∣x′⟩=∫dx∣x⟩⟨x∣x′⟩⟹⟨x∣x′⟩=δ(x−x′)|x'\rangle = \int dx |x\rangle\langle x|x'\rangle \Longrightarrow \langle x|x'\rangle = \delta(x-x')∣x′⟩=∫dx∣x⟩⟨x∣x′⟩⟹⟨x∣x′⟩=δ(x−x′)

From here, we can also further explore the first postulate of QM we talked about in the first post, that a quantum mechanical state is represented by a probability wave function.

Let ψ\psiψ be a normalized state, i.e. ⟨ψ∣ψ⟩=1\langle \psi|\psi\rangle = 1⟨ψ∣ψ⟩=1, we have

1=⟨ψ∣ψ⟩=∫∫dx′dx⟨ψ∣x′⟩⟨x′∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫∫dx′dx⟨ψ∣x′⟩δ(x−x′)⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx⟨ψ∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx∣⟨x∣ψ⟩∣2\begin{aligned} 1 = \langle \psi|\psi\rangle &= \int \int dx' dx \langle \psi|x'\rangle\langle x'|x\rangle\langle x|\psi \rangle \\ &= \int \int dx' dx \langle \psi|x'\rangle \delta(x-x') \langle x|\psi \rangle \\ &= \int dx \langle \psi|x\rangle \langle x|\psi \rangle \\ &= \int dx |\langle x|\psi \rangle|^2 \end{aligned}1=⟨ψ∣ψ⟩​=∫∫dx′dx⟨ψ∣x′⟩⟨x′∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫∫dx′dx⟨ψ∣x′⟩δ(x−x′)⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx⟨ψ∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx∣⟨x∣ψ⟩∣2​

This is where we get the physical explanation that ⟨x∣ψ⟩2\langle x|\psi \rangle^2⟨x∣ψ⟩2 is the probability that the particle is at position xxx. Further, notice that ⟨x∣ψ⟩\langle x|\psi \rangle⟨x∣ψ⟩, the probability of amplitude, is a function of xxx. Here we have the wave function:

ψ(x)=⟨x∣ψ⟩\psi(x) = \langle x|\psi \rangleψ(x)=⟨x∣ψ⟩

The Translation Operator

Now we can talk about the translation operator T^\hat TT^, which should act as follows:

T^(a)∣x⟩=∣x+a⟩\hat T(a) |x\rangle = |x+a\rangleT^(a)∣x⟩=∣x+a⟩

Literally, T^(a)\hat T(a)T^(a) should “move” the state by aaa.

We can act T^\hat TT^ on ∣ψ⟩|\psi\rangle∣ψ⟩ to obtain

∣ψ′⟩=T^∣ψ⟩=∫dx′∣x′+a⟩⟨x′∣ψ⟩|\psi '\rangle = \hat T |\psi\rangle = \int dx'|x'+a\rangle \langle x'|\psi\rangle∣ψ′⟩=T^∣ψ⟩=∫dx′∣x′+a⟩⟨x′∣ψ⟩

with this definition and see how ψ(x)\psi (x)ψ(x) changes to ψ′(x)\psi' (x)ψ′(x):

ψ′(x)=⟨x∣ψ′⟩=∫dx′⟨x∣x+a⟩⟨x′∣ψ⟩=∫dx′δ[x−(x′+a)]⟨x′∣ψ⟩=⟨x−a∣ψ⟩=ψ(x−a)\begin{aligned} \psi '(x) = \langle x|\psi '\rangle &= \int dx'\langle x|x+a\rangle \langle x'|\psi\rangle \\ &= \int dx' \delta[x-(x'+a)] \langle x'|\psi\rangle \\ &= \langle x-a | \psi\rangle = \psi(x-a)\\ \end{aligned}ψ′(x)=⟨x∣ψ′⟩​=∫dx′⟨x∣x+a⟩⟨x′∣ψ⟩=∫dx′δ[x−(x′+a)]⟨x′∣ψ⟩=⟨x−a∣ψ⟩=ψ(x−a)​

This may seem wrong, but think about what happens when you shift a function f(x)f(x)f(x) to the left by aaa: you obtain f(x−a)f(x-a)f(x−a).

Now let’s investigate the representation of the translation operator. Think about the rotation operator Ri^\hat{R_i}Ri​^​ and the time-evolution operator U^\hat UU^ that we’ve discussed in the 2nd and 3rd posts, it shouldn’t be a surprise that we need a generator of translation, which happens to be the momentum operator px^\hat{p_x}px​^​.

T^(dx)=1−iℏpx^dx    T^(a)=e−ipx^a/ℏ\hat T(dx) = 1 - \frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{p_x} dx \; \; \hat T(a) = e^{-i\hat{p_x} a/\hbar}T^(dx)=1−ℏi​px​^​dxT^(a)=e−ipx​^​a/ℏ

The Commutator of the Position and Momentum Operator

The commutator of x^\hat xx^ and px^\hat{p_x}px​^​ very useful and fundamental relationship to obtain:

By applying this infinitesimal limit definition above, we have:

(x^T^(δx)−T^(δx)x^)∣ψ⟩=(−iδxℏ)[x^,px^]∣ψ⟩\Big(\hat x \hat T(\delta x) - \hat T(\delta x) \hat x\Big) |\psi\rangle = \Big(\frac{-i\delta x}{\hbar}\Big)\Big[\hat x, \hat{p_x}\Big] |\psi\rangle(x^T^(δx)−T^(δx)x^)∣ψ⟩=(ℏ−iδx​)[x^,px​^​]∣ψ⟩

By applying the translation operator and position operator directly, we obtain

(x^T^(δx)−T^(δx)x^)∣ψ⟩=(x^T^(δx)−T^(δx)x^)∫dx∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=x^∫dx∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩−T^(δx)∫dx  x∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx(x+δx)∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩−∫dx  x∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=δx∫dx∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=δx∫dx′∣x’⟩⟨x′−δx∣ψ⟩=δx∣ψ⟩\begin{aligned} \Big(\hat x \hat T(\delta x) - \hat T(\delta x) \hat x\Big) |\psi\rangle &= \Big(\hat x \hat T(\delta x) - \hat T(\delta x) \hat x\Big) \int dx|x\rangle \langle x|\psi\rangle \\ &= \hat x \int dx|x+\delta x\rangle \langle x|\psi\rangle - \hat T(\delta x) \int dx \; x |x\rangle \langle x|\psi\rangle \\ &= \int dx (x+\delta x) |x+\delta x\rangle \langle x|\psi\rangle - \int dx \; x |x+\delta x\rangle \langle x|\psi\rangle \\ &= \delta x \int dx |x+\delta x\rangle \langle x|\psi\rangle \\ &= \delta x \int dx' |x’\rangle \langle x'-\delta x|\psi\rangle = \delta x |\psi\rangle\\ \end{aligned}(x^T^(δx)−T^(δx)x^)∣ψ⟩​=(x^T^(δx)−T^(δx)x^)∫dx∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=x^∫dx∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩−T^(δx)∫dxx∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx(x+δx)∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩−∫dxx∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=δx∫dx∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=δx∫dx′∣x’⟩⟨x′−δx∣ψ⟩=δx∣ψ⟩​

where in the last step we keep only the leading-order term of the wave function. Equate the two results, we find that:

[x^,px^]=iℏ⟹ΔxΔpx≥ℏ2\Big[\hat x, \hat{p_x}\Big] = i\hbar \Longrightarrow \Delta x \Delta p_x \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}[x^,px​^​]=iℏ⟹ΔxΔpx​≥2ℏ​

The Ehrenfest Theorem and The Correspondence Principle

Though your intuition for QM now should be enough to convince you that p^x\hat p_xp^​x​ is the momentum operator, let’s validate this by calculating some momentum related quantities. Specifically, let’s start with the energy.

In classical mechanics, we have total energy is equal to mechanical energy and potential energy, or E=px22m+V(x)E = \frac{p^2_x}{2m} + V(x)E=2mpx2​​+V(x), which is translated to the Hamiltonian with the corresponding eigenvalues:

H^=px^22m+V(x^)\hat H = \frac{\hat{p_x}^2}{2m} + V(\hat x)H^=2mpx​^​2​+V(x^)

Recall the result about the time dependence of expectation from post 3,

ddt⟨A⟩=iℏ⟨ψ(t)∣[H^,A^]∣ψ(t)⟩+⟨ψ(t)∣∂A^∂t∣ψ(t)⟩\frac{d}{dt} \langle A\rangle = \frac{i}{\hbar} \langle\psi(t)| \Big[ \hat H, \hat A \Big] |\psi(t)\rangle + \langle\psi(t)| \frac{\partial \hat A}{\partial t}|\psi(t)\rangledtd​⟨A⟩=ℏi​⟨ψ(t)∣[H^,A^]∣ψ(t)⟩+⟨ψ(t)∣∂t∂A^​∣ψ(t)⟩

Using the fact that operators x^\hat xx^ and px^\hat{p_x}px​^​ are time-independent, we can obtain two relationships,

d⟨x⟩dt=iℏ⟨ψ∣[H^,x^]∣ψ⟩=i2mℏ⟨ψ∣[px2^,x^]∣ψ⟩=i2mℏ⟨ψ∣px^[px^,x^]−[x^,px^]px^∣ψ⟩=1m⟨ψ∣px^∣ψ⟩=⟨px⟩m\begin{aligned} \frac{d\langle x\rangle}{dt} &= \frac{i}{\hbar} \langle\psi| \Big[ \hat H, \hat x \Big] |\psi\rangle \\ &= \frac{i}{2m\hbar} \langle\psi| \Big[ \hat{p_x^2}, \hat x \Big] |\psi\rangle \\ &= \frac{i}{2m\hbar} \langle\psi| \hat{p_x} \Big[ \hat{p_x}, \hat x \Big] - \Big[ \hat x, \hat{p_x} \Big] \hat{p_x} |\psi\rangle \\ &= \frac{1}{m} \langle\psi| \hat{p_x} |\psi\rangle = \frac{\langle p_x\rangle}{m} \end{aligned}dtd⟨x⟩​​=ℏi​⟨ψ∣[H^,x^]∣ψ⟩=2mℏi​⟨ψ∣[px2​^​,x^]∣ψ⟩=2mℏi​⟨ψ∣px​^​[px​^​,x^]−[x^,px​^​]px​^​∣ψ⟩=m1​⟨ψ∣px​^​∣ψ⟩=m⟨px​⟩​​
d⟨px⟩dt=iℏ⟨ψ∣[H^,px^]∣ψ⟩=iℏ⟨ψ∣[V(x^),x^]∣ψ⟩=⟨−dVdx⟩\begin{aligned} \frac{d\langle p_x\rangle}{dt} &= \frac{i}{\hbar} \langle\psi| \Big[ \hat H, \hat{p_x} \Big] |\psi\rangle \\ &= \frac{i}{\hbar} \langle\psi| \Big[ V(\hat x), \hat x \Big] |\psi\rangle \\ &= \langle -\frac{dV}{dx}\rangle \end{aligned}dtd⟨px​⟩​​=ℏi​⟨ψ∣[H^,px​^​]∣ψ⟩=ℏi​⟨ψ∣[V(x^),x^]∣ψ⟩=⟨−dxdV​⟩​

The next to last step of the second derivation requires writing out V(x^)V(\hat x)V(x^) as Taylor series and find out [x^n,px^]\Big[ \hat x^n, \hat{p_x} \Big][x^n,px​^​] by the mathematical induction.

These two relationships together,

d⟨x⟩dt=⟨px⟩m    d⟨px⟩dt=⟨−dVdx⟩\frac{d\langle x\rangle}{dt} = \frac{\langle p_x\rangle}{m} \; \; \frac{d\langle p_x\rangle}{dt} = \langle -\frac{dV}{dx}\rangledtd⟨x⟩​=m⟨px​⟩​dtd⟨px​⟩​=⟨−dxdV​⟩

are called the Ehrenfest theorem. It may seem to suggest the expectation values ⟨x⟩,⟨px⟩\langle x\rangle, \langle p_x\rangle⟨x⟩,⟨px​⟩ satisfy the Newton’s second law, but that will require ⟨V(x)⟩=V(⟨x⟩)\langle V(x)\rangle = V(\langle x\rangle)⟨V(x)⟩=V(⟨x⟩), which is not always true. Nevertheless, for the systems widely studied by the classical mechanics, this holds true. The Ehrenfest theorem manifests the correspondence principle, the principle that quantum mechanics reproduce the classical mechanics results in large limits.

The Momentum Operator in the Position Space

Last but not the least, let’s consider the momentum operator’s representation in the position space.

First, we directly apply the translation operator in the position space:

T^(δx)∣ψ⟩=∫dx∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx′∣x⟩⟨x−δx∣ψ⟩=∫dx′∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩−δx∂∂x⟨x′∣ψ⟩=⟨x∣ψ⟩−∫dx′δx∂∂x⟨x′∣ψ⟩\begin{aligned} \hat T(\delta x)|\psi\rangle &= \int dx |x+\delta x\rangle\langle x|\psi\rangle \\ &= \int dx' |x\rangle\langle x - \delta x|\psi\rangle \\ &= \int dx' |x\rangle\langle x|\psi\rangle - \delta x \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \langle x'|\psi\rangle \\ &= \langle x|\psi\rangle - \int dx' \delta x \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \langle x'|\psi\rangle \end{aligned}T^(δx)∣ψ⟩​=∫dx∣x+δx⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩=∫dx′∣x⟩⟨x−δx∣ψ⟩=∫dx′∣x⟩⟨x∣ψ⟩−δx∂x∂​⟨x′∣ψ⟩=⟨x∣ψ⟩−∫dx′δx∂x∂​⟨x′∣ψ⟩​

Then, observe the definition of the translation operator:

T(δx)=1−iℏpx^δxT(\delta x) = 1 - \frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{p_x} \delta xT(δx)=1−ℏi​px​^​δx

We conclude that, in the position space:

px^=ℏi∂∂x\hat{p_x} = \frac{\hbar}{i}\frac{\partial}{\partial x}px​^​=iℏ​∂x∂​

The Momentum Space

In the momentum space, we have basis states as the eigenstates of the momentum operator:

px^∣p⟩=p∣p⟩\hat{p_x}|p\rangle = p|p\ranglepx​^​∣p⟩=p∣p⟩

Similarly to the position space, we have the following representations and relationships:

∣ψ⟩=∫dp∣p⟩⟨p∣ψ⟩|\psi\rangle = \int dp |p\rangle\langle p|\psi\rangle∣ψ⟩=∫dp∣p⟩⟨p∣ψ⟩
⟨p∣p′⟩=δ(p−p′)\langle p|p'\rangle = \delta(p-p')⟨p∣p′⟩=δ(p−p′)
∫dp∣⟨p∣ψ⟩∣2=1\int dp |\langle p|\psi \rangle|^2 = 1∫dp∣⟨p∣ψ⟩∣2=1

What’s interesting and useful is to find out ⟨x∣p⟩\langle x|p\rangle⟨x∣p⟩ so that we can make transitions between the position space and the momentum space.

Luckily, we know the representation of the momentum operator in both spaces:

⟨x∣px^∣p⟩=p⟨x∣p⟩=ℏi∂∂x⟨x∣p⟩\langle x|\hat{p_x}|p\rangle = p\langle x|p\rangle = \frac{\hbar}{i}\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\langle x|p\rangle⟨x∣px​^​∣p⟩=p⟨x∣p⟩=iℏ​∂x∂​⟨x∣p⟩

Solving the differential equation, we get:

⟨x∣p⟩=Neipx/ℏ\langle x|p\rangle = N e^{ipx/\hbar}⟨x∣p⟩=Neipx/ℏ

where NNN is a constant. From this expression, we can already derive the de Broglie wavelength. Notice that the expression is a oscillatory function of xxx with the complex phase p/ℏp/\hbarp/ℏ. Hence the wavelength λ\lambdaλ is 2πp/ℏ=2πℏp\frac{2\pi}{p/\hbar} = \frac{2\pi\hbar}{p}p/ℏ2π​=p2πℏ​, or simply

λ=hp\lambda = \frac{h}{p}λ=ph​

To find the value of the constant, we represent a momentum eigenstate in the position space:

∣p⟩=∫dx∣x⟩⟨x∣p⟩|p\rangle = \int dx |x\rangle\langle x|p\rangle∣p⟩=∫dx∣x⟩⟨x∣p⟩
⟨p′∣p⟩=∫dx⟨p′∣x⟩⟨x∣p⟩=N∗N∫dxei(p−p′)x/ℏ=N∗N(2πℏ)δ(p−p′)=δ(p−p′)\begin{aligned} \langle p'|p\rangle &= \int dx \langle p'|x\rangle\langle x|p\rangle \\ &= N^*N \int dx e^{i(p-p')x/\hbar} \\ &= N^*N (2\pi\hbar) \delta(p-p') = \delta(p-p') \end{aligned}⟨p′∣p⟩​=∫dx⟨p′∣x⟩⟨x∣p⟩=N∗N∫dxei(p−p′)x/ℏ=N∗N(2πℏ)δ(p−p′)=δ(p−p′)​

where we use the Dirac delta’s representation δ(x)=12π∫dk eikx \delta(x) = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int dk \ e^{ikx}δ(x)=2π1​∫dk eikx.

Now we’ve found that N=12πℏN = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\hbar}}N=2πℏ​1​ (I know 2πℏ=h2\pi\hbar = h2πℏ=h, but we the quantum physicists just don’t like hhh…), we can write:

⟨x∣p⟩=12πℏeipx/ℏ\langle x|p\rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\hbar}} e^{ipx/\hbar}⟨x∣p⟩=2πℏ​1​eipx/ℏ

The Solutions to the Schrödinger Equation

Now we have a representation of the momentum operator in the position space, we can first write out the Hamitonian in the position space:

H^=−ℏ22m∂2∂x2+V(x^)\hat H = - \frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\frac{\partial^2}{\partial x^2} + V(\hat x)H^=−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2​+V(x^)

So the time-dependent Schrödinger Equation in the position space is:

[−ℏ22m∂2∂x2+V(x^)]ψ(x,t)=iℏ∂∂tψ(x,t)\Big[ - \frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\frac{\partial^2}{\partial x^2} + V(\hat x) \Big] \psi(x, t) = i\hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(x, t)[−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2​+V(x^)]ψ(x,t)=iℏ∂t∂​ψ(x,t)

Suppose ψ(x)\psi(x)ψ(x) is an energy eigenfunction of the Hamiltonian and ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ\psi(x, t) = \psi(x) e^{-iEt/\hbar}ψ(x,t)=ψ(x)e−iEt/ℏ, we have the time-independent Schrödinger Equation:

[−ℏ22m∂2∂x2+V(x^)]ψ(x)=Eψ(x)\Big[ - \frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\frac{\partial^2}{\partial x^2} + V(\hat x) \Big] \psi(x) = E \psi(x)[−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2​+V(x^)]ψ(x)=Eψ(x)

With this equation and a specific potential function, we can solve the wave equation.

There are many typical 1D problems to solve such as the finite and infinite potential well, scattering, tunneling, the delta function potential, the quantum oscillator. Check out resources online like this post from UVA for more references.

References

[2] Townsend, John. A Modern Approach to Quantum Mechanics. 2nd Edition.
